content:
Yes, Assyrian texts are still studied today by historians, archaeologists, and other scholars. These texts provide valuable insights into ancient Assyrian culture, society, and politics, as well as into the broader history of the ancient Near East.

Scholars can learn a great deal about daily life in ancient Assyria by examining texts related to topics such as economics, law, and religion. For example, cuneiform tablets have been found that contain contracts, business deals, and other legal documents, which provide insights into how the Assyrian economy functioned. In addition, texts related to religious practices and beliefs shed light on the role of religion in Assyrian society.

Assyrian historical records, such as the annals of kings and military campaigns, provide important information about political developments during the Assyrian period, as well as insights into the wider geopolitical landscape of the ancient Near East.

Overall, the study of Assyrian texts remains an active area of research, and ongoing discoveries and examination of existing texts continue to deepen our understanding of this important period in world history.
